results.headline: Review: Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone Aswirl in Tra La La Land
results.summary_short: Ms. Stone and Mr. Gosling sing and dance their way to art and love in Damien Chazelle’s new movie.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of La La Land

results.headline: Review: Katie Holmes Directs Her First Feature, ‘All We Had’
results.summary_short: A teenage girl and her downtrodden mother struggle to build a normal life, but any progress they make seems to unravel.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of All We Had

results.headline: Review: ‘Frank & Lola,’ Retreading Old Ground
results.summary_short: Frankie and Johnny’s story returns, written and directed by Matthew Ross, but not much has changed except the actors and how well they fit together.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Frank & Lola

results.headline: Review: A Trip to Hell, via the VCR, in ‘Beyond the Gates’
results.summary_short: In this horror movie, two brothers play an old-school board game with a videotape and run into Barbara Crampton of “Re-Animator.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Beyond the Gates

results.headline: Review: An Afghan in a Strange Land (California) in ‘Burn Country’
results.summary_short: A former assistant to a war journalist resettles in small-town America, where culture clashes turn mysterious and dangerous.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Burn Country

results.headline: Review: ‘Harry Benson: Shoot First,’ on Photographing the Beatles and Others
results.summary_short: This adulatory profile focuses on a photojournalist who has documented many high-profile figures, but it skips some hard questions.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Harry Benson: Shoot First

results.headline: Review: You’ve Got to Fight for Your Right to an ‘Office Christmas Party’
results.summary_short: Directed by Josh Gordon and Will Speck, this bawdy comedy is full of familiar faces, including Kate McKinnon and Courtney B. Vance, behaving badly.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Office Christmas Party

results.headline: Review: The Team That Put Israeli Basketball ‘On the Map’
results.summary_short: Dani Menkin’s documentary recounts this team’s unlikely run to the European Cup championship in 1977, a year in Israel’s history that was more fraught than usual.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of On the Map

results.headline: Review: ‘Slash’ Has Proud Outcasts With Bold Imaginations
results.summary_short: This sweet-natured coming-of-age movie is perhaps more complicated than most by having characters whose sexual orientations are in flux.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Slash

results.headline: Review: You Quit? Think Again, ‘Sword Master’
results.summary_short: A swordsman has grown tired of his work and his love in this remake of “Death Duel,” a nod to the Chinese magic-and-martial arts genre wuxia.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sword Master

results.headline: Review: Isabelle Huppert Is Great in ‘Things to Come.’ Discuss.
results.summary_short: In this film by Mia Hansen-Love, Ms. Huppert plays a philosophy professor who must reassemble her life after a series of personal catastrophes.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Things to Come

results.headline: Review: In ‘Two Trains Runnin’,’ the Convergence of Idealism, Brutality and Artistic Genius
results.summary_short: This captivating movie, like the blues itself, is at once a recognition of somber truths and a gesture of protest against them.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Two Trains Runnin’

results.headline: Review: ‘Best and Most Beautiful Things,’ About a Disabled Woman’s Place in the World
results.summary_short: This documentary follows a young woman who is legally blind and has Asperger’s syndrome as she enters adulthood and explores a new identity.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Best and Most Beautiful Things

results.headline: Review: A Woman’s Horrific Unraveling in ‘The Eyes of My Mother’
results.summary_short: A dark maturation unfolds in this story, from a child coolly absorbing an anatomy lesson to a traumatized adult taking on a more participatory role in death.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Eyes of My Mother

results.headline: Review: ‘Hogtown’ Tells a Poetic Detective Story in Chicago
results.summary_short: The movie, which revolves around a disappearance, unfolds in loosely connected vignettes and can feel as if it’s a collection of poems.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hogtown

results.headline: ‘Jackie’: Under the Widow’s Weeds, a Myth Marketer
results.summary_short: Natalie Portman is perfect in Pablo Larraín’s multifaceted portrait of the former first lady Jacqueline Kennedy as an embodiment of grief and as an architect of brilliant political theater.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jackie

results.headline: Review: ‘The Duelist’ Is a Good Shot. A Very Good Shot.
results.summary_short: In this Aleksey Mizgirev film set in 1860 St. Petersburg, an ex-nobleman makes his living as a proxy in honor matches of shooting skill.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Duelist

results.display_title: Goodnight Brooklyn: The Story of Death by Audio
results.headline: Review: ‘Goodnight Brooklyn: The Story of Death by Audio,’ Alive in Spirit
results.summary_short: This documentary follows the closing of Death by Audio, a communal space in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, that was taken over by Vice Media.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Goodnight Brooklyn: The Story of Death by Audio

results.headline: Review: ‘Man Down’ Looks at Combat Trauma Through a Marine’s Eyes
results.summary_short: Dito Montiel’s film, which stars Shia LaBeouf as a scarred veteran, imparts the urgency of its issue more effectively with statistics than with its script.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Man Down

results.headline: Review: That ‘Pet’ at the Shelter Looks Like a Caged Woman
results.summary_short: This Carles Torrens film centers on a psychological duel between an animal shelter worker and a former crush.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pet
